Oregon Governor Kate Brown is extending the statewide school closure until April 28. The governor made the announcement this evening with a new executive order.

Along with extending the school closure for six weeks, the order issued further guidance to the state’s public schools including:

- Districts are to provide learning supports and supplemental services to students and families during the closure period.

- School districts may call on public school educators and employees to deliver limited learning and support services. Each district will pay all their regular employees during the closure.

- The Oregon Department of Education, Oregon Health Authority, and Department of Human Services are directed to support public schools in the continuity of mental health services.

The Sweet Home School District is working on a plan to comply with the Governor's executive order.

Thank you for your cooperation and understanding during this challenging time. As always, we will continue to keep you as updated as possible with information.

Sweet Home’s graduation rate improved by 13.7 percent over the prior year to 84.5 percent, one of the largest increases in the state.

Oregon Public Broadcasting featured Sweet Home in a recent story about school districts with improved graduation rates. It’s worth noting that Sweet Home had the highest overall graduation rate among the districts mentioned. Portland’s graduation rate was at 80.5 percent, Bethel was at 75.5 percent, Crook County was at 72.9 percent, Estacada was at 66.1 percent and Coquille was at 61.1 percent.

Oregon’s statewide average was 80 percent, an all-time high since the state tightened how it tracks the graduation rate more than a decade ago.

Great job to the parents and staff members who helped Sweet Home’s students. Most of all, tremendous job to Sweet Home’s students who worked hard to earn their diplomas. We are extremely proud of you!

We ask parents to be alert for stomach bug symptoms (diarrhea, stomach or intestinal cramps, nausea, vomiting, fever, weight loss, joint aches, muscle aches) and to keep kids at home if they are exhibiting symptoms. In addition, please keep kids home for an extra 48 hours after symptoms have stopped.

The health and well-being of our students is of the utmost importance. While we still have only one student with a documented case of Norovirus, we want to do everything we can to protect students attending all of our schools.

We will continue to monitor and keep you informed.

Thank you so much to the staff members, contractors and volunteers that have done an amazing job getting our buildings ready for students when school begins on Tuesday. It has been a huge undertaking especially with the major construction projects at Foster, Holley and Sweet Home Junior High School this summer.

Some finishing work will need to be completed at Holley and Foster after school begins. Both schools have plans in place to accommodate the work while delivering educational programming.

Work on the Junior High School’s new entrance, office area, auxiliary gym and cafeteria will continue into the spring of 2020. These areas will remain off limits until work is complete.

Here are pictures of Foster's new stamped concrete entrance and a classroom with new energy efficient windows. We hope you like the facility improvements as much as we do.

Sweet Home Junior High School teachers were directed to hold students in class at 12:05 p.m. this afternoon while the school resource officer, school administration and police investigated a single student’s report of a suspicious person spotted around our campus.

Students remained engaged in normal educational activities during the 4th period section while the report was being investigated by law enforcement and school staff. After a thorough review and investigation, the threat was deemed non-credible and classes resumed as normal.

We take all threats seriously because keeping students safe is our chief responsibility. Tonight, we ask each parent to review with their son and daughter the importance of making good choices as well as “seeing something, saying something” to help others stay safe too.

Hawthorne Elementary School is full of construction activity this summer.

A seismic retrofit project is underway to upgrade the school to life safety standards in case of a major earthquake. The seismic project is funded by a grant from the Oregon Infrastructure Authority.

Separately, the Sweet Home School District facilities team is hard at work making the school more secure. This project includes constructing a security vestibule entrance adjacent to a renovated front office area. The security vestibule will divert all visitors through the administration area before they can access the rest of the school. The project also includes visual surveillance improvements, a new health room and adding a small conference room.

Sweet Home High School graduate Dr. James McCarthy has been awarded the 2018 Tyler Prize for Environmental Achievement -- an international award that recognizes individuals in the scientific community for increasing understanding of how Earth's climate works.

Dr. McCarthy is a professor of biological oceanography at Harvard University. At Harvard, Dr. McCarthy has been instrumental in creating the institution's undergraduate degree program in Environmental Science and Public Policy. He also directed Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology from 1982 to 2002. Dr. McCarthy continues to teach ocean science and advise students.

Dr. McCarthy grew up in Sweet Home and graduated from Sweet Home High School in 1962.

The Sweet Home School District Board of Directors is considering placing a $4 million bond on the May 16, 2017 ballot for voters to decide. If voters pass the bond, Sweet Home may be able to double its money by receiving an additional $4 million grant from the Oregon School Capital Improvement Matching Program providing a total of $8 million for school improvements. The grant is intended to help districts with low property values raise enough funds to make needed facility improvements without overburdening taxpayers. If voters reject the bond measure, the $4 million grant would be diverted to another school district.

The School Board will need to decide whether or not to pursue the bond and matching grant. To help decide, the Board has asked for input from community members, parents and staff through the survey at the following link... https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/Facility_Bond

Hard copy surveys are also being distributed from school sites to gain as much input as possible. Thank you for providing your input.

Stanford University psychologist Carol Dweck has performed decades of research on achievement and success. She defines a fixed mindset as those who believe their basic qualities, like intelligence or talent, are simply fixed traits. They also believe that talent alone creates success — without effort. In a growth mindset, people believe that their basic abilities can be developed through dedication and hard work. This view creates a love of learning and a resilience that is essential for great accomplishment.

What do you think?

Congratulations to Holley Elementary School for having the highest attendance rate in the school district during the month of May. Here are the results:

1. Holley Elementary 94.48%
2. Oak Heights Elementary 94.14%
3. Hawthorne Elementary 94.07%
4. Foster Elementary 93.50%
5. Sweet Home Junior High 93.06%
6. Sweet Home Charter School 92.79%
7. Sweet Home High School 84.42%

For the full year (September 2015 through May 2016), there is a very close race for first place with Holley in the lead at 94.25% followed closely by Oak Heights at 94.21% and Hawthorne at 94.08%.

Our district facilities staff has been busy making improvements to the swim pool while the facility has been closed including installing new energy efficient LED lights. Here is a before and after picture.

We plan to have a limited pool reopening on Tuesday, May 31 with a public lap swim from 11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and a family swim from 7 p.m. to 8:30 p.m.

We will announce a more complete pool schedule next week. We hope to resume a full schedule soon. Thank you for your patience.

The new swim pool boiler arrived today. The boiler will be set in place and installation work will begin this week and is scheduled to wrap up next week. Assuming the installation goes smoothly, we will be able to fire up the boiler and have it inspected during the middle of next week. We will reopen the pool once the water is warm enough.

Thank you for your patience. We look forward to reopening the pool as soon as we can. We will continue to provide updates regarding the status of the pool on the District website and Facebook page.

The Holley Elementary School Parent Teacher Club annual auction is tonight (Friday, May 6) at 5 p.m. at the Elks Lodge.

Hamburger and hot dog meals will be available for $8 and both silent and live auctions will be held.

Auction items include OSU football tickets, wine tasting, golf rounds, truck loads of wood chips, party packages, music festival tickets and much more.

The Elks Lodge is located at 440 Osage Street.
